Introductory Matters

Class 1, Tuesday, September 9
Topic: Introductory Matters
    After some introductory material, in this session we will ask why we should study religion. We will also explore the ways in which Furman's history and heritage influence that answer in this context. As part of that discussion students will learn a bit about fundamentalism and the history of the Furman's relationship with the SC Baptists. 

Class 2, Wednesday, September 11
Topic: What is Religion; What is Scripture?
    In this class period we will look at some of the issues in the study of religion. What is it? Do all religions speak of God? Can we say Scripture is the "Word of God?" What is involved in such statements? How do different academic disciplines regard religion? 
Assignment: 
1) Genesis 2 and 3 
    Think especially about the religious questions this text addresses. 
2) Text, pp. 1-8 (copies distributed in class)
3)  Read in the Bible: Nehemiah 9:6-37 and Acts 7:1-52  These are Biblical summaries of sacred history.  What is the perspective of these texts? How are the accounts in Nehemiah and Acts different?  
4)  Begin reading Kimball.  (You will need to read up to page 40 for Thursday)

Part II:  Historical Overview

Goals for the Unit:
   1.  Begin to understand the nature of the historical enterprise as different from the religious endeavor.
    2.  See the way in which Biblical religion (and thus, religion in general) changes in response to historical and cultural events.  
    3.  Recognize the role interpretation plays in the process, i.e.  different people use the same stories and texts in different ways.  

Question for Thought and Discussion:
    How does the view that certain cultural and historical events influenced the nature and development of the biblical religion relate to your view of faith.  Is there a way to hold this view and be a person of faith?

2. The number 8 is an important biblical number.  Jews perform circumcision (the birth into the religious community for Jewish males) on the 8th day of life. In early Christianity the number 8 also symbolized rebirth, and baptismal pools often had 8 sides.  Some early Christians referred to Sunday as the 8th day of creation.   Go to this page Link and click on the section called Chanukah Insights.  Read the brief discussion of Hanukkah from the Lubavitcher Rebbe entitled.  "The Obligation to Illuminate the World," which is found at the link called "Light over Darkness."  (Read other links if you like.)  Based on the insights found here about Hannukkah and on your understanding of the symbolism of the temple write 1-3 paragraphs about the way in which Hanukkah symbolizes the meaning of Judaism even if it is a minor holiday.   Maximum of 1 page no smaller than 10 pitch and at with at least 1.5 line spacing.  A "B" answer will have basic thoughtful ideas.  An "A" answer will make more connections.  (15 points)
